bullets.text: At Davos, Trump claimed a Greenland “framework” with NATO and signaled backing off Europe tariff threats, easing immediate trade-war risk and sparking a risk-on rally.
Large, policy-driven equity swings after tariff reversals highlight elevated regime uncertainty for investors, even when near-term outcomes turn market-friendly.
Supreme Court appears poised to block Trump from immediately firing Fed Governor Lisa Cook, reinforcing legal constraints supporting central-bank independence.
Trump floated a 10% credit-card APR cap; policy risk shifts to bank margins, credit availability, and potential unintended tightening for subprime borrowers.
Pending home sales fell sharply in December, signaling housing demand softness and a weaker early-2026 outlook despite political focus on affordability.
Arctic storm risk pushed U.S. natural-gas prices sharply higher, underscoring winter weather sensitivity for energy inflation and utility/industrial costs.
Japan export growth missed estimates as shipments to the U.S. plunged, signaling trade sensitivity to U.S. demand and tariff uncertainty.
South Korea’s Q4 growth slowed to 1.5% as construction and exports fell, a warning sign for a semiconductor- and trade-linked economy.
JPMorgan’s Jamie Dimon criticized Trump’s immigration approach, highlighting business concern about labor supply, growth, and reputational spillovers.
OpenAI and Anthropic pushed enterprise adoption at Davos, signaling the next growth phase: deployment, governance, and ROI-driven spending, not just model performance.
Meta rolling out Threads ads globally expands monetization inventory, intensifying competition for digital ad budgets alongside X, TikTok, and YouTube.
Blue Origin launched a satellite-internet service, escalating LEO broadband competition with SpaceX and Amazon and raising capital-intensity stakes in the connectivity race.
Princeton security researchers argue internet voting remains fundamentally insecure, implying high systemic election-risk and a strong case for paper-auditable ballots.
Stanford researchers report cartilage regrowth and arthritis prevention in early work, a potential step-change for a massive chronic-care market if clinically replicated.
Scientists are engineering viruses to fight antibiotic-resistant bacteria, a promising anti-superbug strategy that could reshape infectious-disease pipelines and hospital outcomes.
